I'm not opening a bank account or trading stocks.If a company demands draconian KYC verification to make a simple purchase, I'll never, ever, do business with them again.Bye bye Dynadot.

Results from tap counting indicate that this site's useability continues its downward trend, perhaps in part (and I don't mean to speculate too wildly here) that their development environment diverges too radically from their users' environments, e.g., with screen size. If anyone from Dynadot has the chance to get up to Fremont, WA, they should walk along the canal to the Adobe campus, go to the back of the building on the east side, and look at Adobe's test facility for inspiration.

Review.Titre: CONGRESS: these domain companies are FLEECING US
Review.Contenu: I had some notices for expired domains go by unseen for a month or so. I then find out I have to pay $85 or more to renew them. I also discover, to my horror, that one of my domains that I have paid for, over years, and use for business, was about to go to auction. Is it not time for ICANN or whoever oversees this, i.e Congress, to finally put these wholly unfair practices to sleep? If we miss some emails because they went to junk, we then have zero option but to pay these exorbitant fees for 'restoration' that is surely as automated as anything else out there. No human effort. Just click and it's done.Am I on another planet, or are 10 X charges like this -- that is, charging someone ten times what we should normally pay to renew a domain -- unfair, probably collusion, likely considered unfair practice and, from what I can tell, a host of what would otherwise be considered non-competitive behaviour in any other line of business? Please, Congress, if you're listening, make it stop. Finally. And help get us REPAID

Be certain that *none of your serious concerns and specific needs will be handled. If you look for cheap, fast, automated registration, Dynadot is probably the cheapest, but be sure that's all you need because that's all you will get. Dynadot is just another money pump, borderline fraudulent company.

Review.Titre: Inconsiderate Privacy Policies & Terrible Customer Support
Review.Contenu: Do not sign up unless you wish for your details to be  difficult to delete and only removed by the discretion of Dynadot, regardless of privacy laws.I wanted to first close my Dynadot account, they stated they could not delete my account as I "had an active domain tied to it", I didn't, it was a glitch on their website. I told them to look at the WHOIS information for the glitched domain, which clearly shows it's now connected/transferred to a different registar, they ignored my request and just sent the same macro response stating "I have an active domain tied to it so it cannot be deleted" over and over again. I decided to reach out to their live chat instead of email, and they realized the mistake and opened a ticket to their engineers on my behalf. Sucks that I had to go through live chat as the customer support through email was just simply ignoring my details.After getting my account closed, and moving on to getting it deleted - Dynadot does not respect or understand GDPR. They replied to my account deletion request saying "GDPR applies to companies based in the UK. We are based in the United States. Our governing body is ICANN and we are compliant with their requirements. "The GDPR's territorial scope extends beyond the geographical boundaries of the European Union (EU) or European Economic Area (EEA). Article 3 of the GDPR explicitly outlines that the regulation applies to businesses processing the personal data of individuals who are located within the EU or EEA, regardless of the business's physical location.And aside from that, it's just plainly inconsiderate for a company to not delete your account when requested, with all the data breaches and such going on.

Review.Titre: Save a dollar, to Lose 10 dollars
Review.Contenu: at one time they were great (back when they were new in the scene, and actually cared about their customers), but now their just a hollowed out garbage company only cares about the $$, not about their customers or what they have to do to get the $$. I had 1 of their services which they were planning on shutting down, I renewed the service for another year only to find out about a month later that they were shutting it down at the end of the year, (4mo after renewal), and this is when the fun begins, they receive a "copyright complaint" and regardless of all the data I sent them contesting it and proving it false, still ended up getting a 2 week service suspension, once the suspension was lifted, the routing never got reset properly and only had intermittent access to the server with >50% downtime/outage on the service, and then finally, durring 1 of the services downtime/outage while its unaccessable to the public, they receive a "copyright complaint" which resulted in a PERMANENT SERVICE SUSPENSION, that way at the end of the year when they shutdown the service they dont have a 8mo service refund / buy out to send me, I then pulled out the rest of my services with them and transfered them to other hosts.They may have saved themselves some pocket change, and cost me a couple hundred with services, migrations, rebuilding the lost, and thren lost business from service outages, so on... but, and I take pride in saying it, even with a smile, I cant even tally up to total monthly revenue they lost (more then the pocket change they saved) with their $$ saving stunt.The date of experience listed was the last communication received from them pulling out the plausable deniability card claiming it was their parent host doing the suspension, not them.
Worst registrar I've EVER use. Just don't use it, trust me.

Review.Titre: Unreliable, not gmail compatible unless buying extra package
Review.Contenu: Probably only good as a zero frills registrar service if you already have a web hosting package. Not a good choice if you just want a domain and a custom inbox. Web hosting options limited & rely on use of their site builder. Multiple issues I encountered after transfer:1. If you're a less experienced user used to having a mailbox as part of your domain registration (I did for the last 10 years with several registrars), be aware this is something you have to pay extra for with Dynadot (which for me works out more expensive than previously when you add on email hosting package). After realising this I then reverted to trying their provided mailbox whilst I can set up web hosting (meanwhile my email is out of action)..2. The mailbox provided with their free website builder package   cannot be used with gmail. Customer support confirmed to use POP with gmail you have to buy the £90!! annual subscription...absolute joke. Their email client is dreadful, very limited options for customisation e.g can't have an image or change fonts in email signature. And now have to reply to everything via that instead of conveniently on my gmail app. Soon as my web hosting is set up WITH ANOTHER PROVIDER I will be switching mail hosting asap.3. Help not available during several attempts to set up DNS settings and mailbox4. After initial Inbox set-up (which did not receive messages) it is finally working so I am left forwarding mails to gmail so I am alerted daily and then logging on to their (html only) client to reply. So long-winded and this whole process has been a DISASTER and huge waste of my time - will be going back to 1&1 for domain & email.

Dynadot is the best overall, but they deserve some protesting, because there is no improvements on some of their mistakes (others don't care, this is why they keep them).1. They display PPC ads by default. And those ads can be used by evil companies with trademark, and their evil UDRP partners to steal your domain. None of your domains are safe because all domains have parts which resemale trademarks. As long as there are PPC ads on landing pages, you are potentially donating your domains to your enemies, and you can get them back only by spending time and money to reverse evil UDRP's decision in court, and it may still fail.2. If evil UDRP wants your whois info they just surrenders it. And evil UDRP uses your whois info in inappropriate ways, such as mixing UDRP complaints to benefit complainants, even if complainants don't make claims based on domain owners' identity. So evil UDRP can use one of their unfair decisions to support another of their unfair decision despite GDRP. 3. Their marketplace is great but, they give no hints about seller's identity, and there is lots of rooms for manipulation. These may not be important for most people and most domains, but for some people they can be extremely important. If these are corrected I would give them 5.Dynadot is great for domain buyers, just buy the domain, but not park there, and start using it immediately.

I purchased about 40 domains in a 3 day window from Dynadot. I mainly buy domains that have just expired, so time is gold.3 instances registration took more than an hour, luckily for me the domains were successfully registered. after submitting a number of verifications, I thought my next purchase would go smoother. I placed an order at late hours of the day ( not much traffic) the order was pending till I contacted them on the evening of the next day, however one domain got registered by someone else in the meantime (also the other domains were available to grab up until I contacted their support).When asked about why am I losing a very valuable (2 words,.com, nohyphens, nonumbers) domain, they replied "The domain was registered elsewhere before the order processed, unfortunately.  Sorry, we did not get it registered for you in time."

There's being careful with fraud, and then there's being too careful. I bought a domain from Dynadot and, whilst it all went through successfully and I received the domain instantly, my account was 'randomly selected' for a fraud check.So I was told to verify my phone number. Fine, that was a quick enough process. 1 hour later I receive an automated e-mail asking for me to verify my details were all correct and accurate, again as part of a fraud check. Then not long after I received yet another e-mail this time from an actual representative to my PayPal address (not the account's address), asking if I authorised the transaction. At this point I was a quite annoyed because I had already proven twice that the order was genuine, I didn't feel trusted and certainly didn't feel like they were believing I was a real customer to them - which is unfortunate, because whilst I completely understand fraud checks are a necessity in business, their procedure for checking is completely out of control and seems to be very illogical. It made me feel completely uncomfortable with the company - at least check the most common methods of fraud (use of a proxy, different country purchase to billing country, etc) before instantly suspecting of fraud.Frankly, they should have stopped at the phone verification. Or have just stuck with one verification method that was most convenient to them, rather than using more than one method. This was frustrating because they could not verify my PayPal e-mail with my actual account e-mail because the PayPal address wasn't an active address (it was essentially a 'no reply' account). I suggest that they improve their fraudulent transaction checking procedures, otherwise so far no other bad experiences.

Fantastic experience so far with domain transfers (in), excellent pricing compared to anyone else I've looked at, and very helpful Support.I have only two *tiny* niggles:(1) It is not always obvious how to get back to the 'home' page using the menu system, for example after paying for a transfer-in: it seems you need to hover or click on your name to get back 'home'.  Others have complained about the non-intuitive interface and I suggest it needs a little work.(2) Two-factor Authentication is a great security feature, but Dynadot automatically logs me out after too short a period (1 hour? Less?) which means I have to keep doing 2FA throughout the day if I'm using my Dynadot account and doing other things at the same time.  I understand that this is for security purposes, but for those using a private computer at home, being repeatedly logged out and required to go through 2FA is unnecessary and tedious (and costs Dynadot additional 2FA fees).  I suggest an "Are you on a public computer?" prompt or similar when logging in.
